summary: Defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim writes to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting clarification on whether electronic documents can be used for impeachment or refreshing witness recollection at Ghislaine Maxwell's trial, proposing a procedure to display documents only on screens not visible to the gallery or jury to protect witness privacy while ensuring trial efficiency.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, submitting a letter to the court proposing a procedure for document display during trial to protect witness privacy and ensure efficient proceedings.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge presiding over the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom the defense's letter is addressed requesting clarification on trial procedures.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case S2 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), whose defense team is submitting this procedural request to the court.

connections.description: Sternheim is the defense attorney representing Maxwell in her criminal trial, as indicated by the letter being submitted on Maxwell's behalf.
Defense attorney communicating with the presiding judge regarding trial procedures and requesting clarification on document display protocols.

events.title: Court Discussion on Document Procedures
events.description: Previous court discussion regarding the use of documents containing identifying information for witnesses testifying under pseudonyms, which the defense understood to apply only to such documents.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense is requesting clarification on whether electronic documents can be used for impeachment or refreshing witness recollection, rather than requiring paper copies for all such uses.
Witnesses in the trial are testifying under pseudonyms, requiring special procedures to protect their identities from the courtroom gallery.
The defense proposes displaying documents only on video screens used by the witness, court, and court deputyâ€”screens that do not face the gallery or jury box.
The government opposes the defense's proposed procedure, expressing concern that jurors might see the witness screen, though the defense notes jurors are permitted to know witness identities.
The letter reveals ongoing procedural disputes between defense and prosecution regarding trial efficiency and witness privacy protections.
